August 16, 1987: Fiction
PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) Jack Ryan vs. international
terrorists.
PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A
brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians.
MISERY, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) An author is held captive by a
psychotic fan.
WEEP NO MORE, MY LADY, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.)
Love and murder at a swank California health spa.
DIRK GENTLY'S HOLISTIC DETECTIVE AGENCY, by Douglas Adams. (Simon &
Schuster, $14.95.) A private eye's trip through time.
THE HAUNTED MESA, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $18.95.) Unraveling the
mystery of Indian cliff dwellers who vanished centuries ago.
WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) Nightmarish
experiences befall a woman appointed Ambassador to Rumania.
FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) A son of the 60's on his way
to the 80's.
SPHERE, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $17.95.) Four scientists explore an alien
spaceship.
EMPIRE, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $22.50.) Turn-of-the-century
Washington.
THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Complex
family relationships in South Carolina and New York City.
MORE DIE OF HEARTBREAK, by Saul Bellow. (Morrow, $17.95.) The many-
faceted relationship of the narrator and his uncle, a famous botanist.
THE TIMOTHY FILES, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $18.95.) A veteran turned
detective.
FIRST BORN, by Doris Mortman. (Bantam, $17.95.) The rivalry of sisters and
cousins played out in the worlds of high fashion and politics.
TO SAIL BEYOND THE SUNSET, by Robert A. Heinlein. (Ace/Putnam, $18.95.) A
pastiche of themes and characters from earlier works.
HEIRESS, by Janet Dailey. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) Sisters vie for their father's
affection and fortune.
August 16, 1987
Non-Fiction
SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright. (Viking, $19.95.) The autobiography of a former
senior member of the British secret service.
THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster,
$18.95.) A critique of liberal arts education during the past 25 years.
LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A
surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions.
THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.)
An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade.
CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) Information
- history, literature, politics - that you need to read with.
CALL ME ANNA, by Patty Duke and Kenneth Turan. (Bantam, $17.95.) The
autobiography of the actress and show business personality.
WITNESS TO A CENTURY, by George Seldes. (Ballantine, $19.95.)
Recollections of a veteran journalist.
A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AMERICA. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The nation on
May 2, 1986, as recorded in pictures by 200 photojournalists.
COMMUNION, by Whitley Strieber. (Beech Tree/ Morrow, $17.95.) A professional
writer tells of the visits of ''intelligent nonhumans'' to his home.
HAMMER, by Armand Hammer with Neil Lyndon. (Putnam, $22.95.) The
industrialist's memoirs.
THE DIFFERENT DRUM, by M. Scott Peck. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) A
psychiatrist's prescription for personal and communal peace.
LIFE AND DEATH IN SHANGHAI, by Nien Cheng. (Grove, $19.95.) China's
Cultural Revolution as experienced by a wealthy woman accused of spying for the
West.
AND A VOICE TO SING WITH, by Joan Baez. (Summit, $19.95.) The memoirs of
the folk singer who became a political activist in the 1960's.
THE SPY WORE RED, by Aline, Countess of Romanones. (Random House,
$18.95.) Recollections of a woman who served as an undercover agent in Europe
during World War II.
EVERYTHING TO GAIN, by Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter. (Random House,
$16.95.) How the Carters are making the most of the rest of their lives.
